In City jargon it has agreed £600m worth of term loan facilities and an £800m revolving credit facility, to replace the loans currently provided by the government.

These new new debt facilities will mean a "a significant reduction in the Group's overall cost of debt", it says -- in other words, it will be able to borrow from commercial banks at a cheaper rate than from the Department for Business.

Good news for Royal Mail, but presumably a loss of revenue for the taxpayer (Robert Peston reckons it's paying an interest rate of 8.8% - roughly three times as much as the government can borrow for 10 years)

9.36am BST

The BBC's Robert Peston is also intrigued by the prospect of Royal Mail floating on the stock market in the midst of a strike action:

I can certainly never remember any business being sold on the stock market at a time when it had been brought to a grinding halt by a strike. But that does not mean a flotation in those circumstances can't and won't happen.

There is the very real, or perhaps surreal, prospect, of postal workers simultaneously downing tools (parking their trolleys) and subscribing a few hundred quid for Royal Mail shares.

9.32am BST

Business minister Michael Fallon suggested on Radio 4 this morning that industrial action is unlikely (our political correspondent Rowena Mason flags up)

Speaking on the Today programme, Fallon acknowledged that staff have "concerns" about the future of Royal Mail but said he did not expect a proposed strike to go ahead. 

Echoing some of the points he made on Sky News (see 7.36am), Fallon said:

I don’t think the strike is necessary...There's a very generous pay off on the table. They've been offered 8.6% over three years, and I think the rest of the public sector is only getting 1% a year. It’s a very generous pay-off, there are free shares on offer as well, so I don’t see any reason for a strike.

But as I mentioned up at 8.07am, this morning's announcement clearly warns prospective investors that Royal Mail anticipates strike action on or after 10 October....

9.21am BST

Rafael Behr, political editor of the New Statesman, reckons the sale could prove a hot potato for Labour if it can't promise to renationalise the Royal Mail service.

9.17am BST

It's not too late to stop the selloff, Umunna concludes - pointing out that unions will be meeting with the Royal Mail CEO Moya Greene later today.

Updated at 9.20am BST

9.15am BST

Chuka Umunna also dismissed the idea that members of the public will dash to buy Royal Mail shares, given the minimum allocation of £750 (or £500 for staff who want more than their £2,000 free allocation).

If you're earning a lot of money in the Cabinet, that's not a lot of money, but it's a lot to the man on the street, he says.

Umunna reiterates his point from this morning that the government is now privatising the Royal Mail's profits, having nationalised its losses by putting its pension deficit on the public books.

9.12am BST

Chuka Umunna, the shadow business secretary, is on BBC News 24 now, criticising the selloff:

He warns that there's no guarantee in the long-term that a privatised Royal Mail won't sell off sorting offices and other operations in prime city locations, which could hurt customers.

This is bad for consumers, and bad in particular for small businesses.

But will Labour reverse the sale? Umunna says he can't make any commitments to renationalising Royal Mail in the future.

It would be like writing a blank cheque.

9.01am BST

City firm ETX Capital reckons that the IPO will be priced "very attractively", to avoid the embarrassment of some shares being left unsold.

Joe Rundle, head of trading, says:

We expect it to be priced very attractively by the government in order to garner the demand to deem this IPO as a success given the importance surrounding it. 

8.51am BST

The Financial Times also flags up that even Margaret Thatcher couldn't face selling off the Royal Mail, pointing out that at least 41% of the company will be offered to City institutions and the public, on top of the 10% handed to staff.

Updated at 8.51am BST

8.46am BST

News Story: Government to float Royal Mail on stock exchange 'in the coming weeks'

Our full news story about the Royal Mail privatisation is now live, by Rupert Neate. Here's a flavour:

The sell-off of the 497-year-old postal service is the most contentious privatisation since British Rail two decades ago, and is forcefully opposed by the unions, who are meeting with the Royal Mail chief executive, Moya Greene, on Thursday morning to once again voice their anger at the "great British flog-off".

The Communication Workers Union (CWU) plans to disrupt the sale process by holding a strike ballot on 20 September, which could lead to a nationwide strike by 10 October. It would be the first nationwide postal strike since 2009. The union is also pushing for a better pay deal, after rejecting a 8.6% pay rise over three years.

Billy Hayes, general secretary of the CWU, said 96% of Royal Mail staff oppose the sell-off, which "not even Thatcher dared do".

Margaret Thatcher, who privatised British Gas, British Airways, British Telecom and dozens of other state-owned institutions in the 1980s, famously refused to countenance a sale of Royal Mail, saying she was "not prepared to have the Queen's head privatised".

Government to float Royal Mail on stock exchange 'in the coming weeks'

Updated at 10.44am BST

8.32am BST

The privatisation has also been criticised by Paul Wheelhouse MSP, a member of the Scottish Nationalist Party in the Scottish Parliament. He fears it will lead to deteriorating services in rural areas

8.30am BST

It's all the European Union's fault, according to UKIP's Nigel Farage:

That's a reference to the EU's Postal Directive, which aims to create a Single Market for postal services.

The EU has denied in the past, though, that it is responsible for the closure of rural post offices (there's a rebuttal online here), saying that its laws 'enshrine' the universal service obligation.

8.22am BST

The government helped to pave the way for the sale last year by transferring the Royal Mail pension fund (and its historic deficit of over £9bn) onto the public books.

This makes the business rather more attractive to private buyers, as Labour's Chuka Umunna tweets:

8.14am BST

On page 15 of today's Announcement, the government warns potential investors that members of the Communications Workers Union will probably go on strike next month, possibly as early as 10 October.

That strike action is over pay, pension reforms, the impact privatisation will have on staff, and the Royal Mail future strategy.

Here's the key section:

• Negotiations between Royal Mail and the CWU are continuing and Royal Mail remains committed to reaching an agreement with the CWU and averting industrial action. However, there can be no guarantee that negotiations will lead to a successful outcome or the aversion of industrial action. 

• Royal Mail currently believes that the relevant members of the CWU will vote for national industrial action and that national industrial action and other forms of industrial action are therefore expected to
take place across the whole of UKPIL's activities on or after 10 October 2013. In the event of national industrial action, the Group has contingency plans in place and will also consider its legal options

8.07am BST

Could the government push through the Royal Mail selloff before unions have the chance to strike?

ITV's Laura Kuenssberg reckons so, writing that "the race is on" to get the share sale out of the door before October 10 - the earliest possible day for a strike action.

That sounds potentially risky -- will investors really want to snap up shares in a company whose staff are poised to walk out?....

7.59am BST

George Thomson, general secretary of the National Federation of Sub-Postmasters, has also heavily criticised the plan:

I am extremely disappointed and concerned that the Government is pressing ahead with a plan that will undoubtedly jeopardise the future of thousands of post offices.

We simply have not had the promised new Government work that needs to be delivered before the sale of Royal Mail and which would safeguard the future survival of an independent Post Office. 

Thomson has called for the government to "halt the sale" until this new work is forthcoming -- unlikely, I suspect, given Michael Fallon's obvious enthusiasm on Sky News a few minutes ago.

He also wants the government to hold a significant share of the company after privatisation, to give the public some control over their postal service (today's announcement simply says the government "intends to dispose of a majority of Royal Mail’s issued share capital").

7.50am BST

Labour: government is ploughing on despite opposition

The Labour party has blasted the decision to begin floating Royal Mail on the stock market.

Chuka Umunna, the shadow business secretary, says there's a "huge coalition" against the plan, but ministers are "ploughing on regardless".

Here's his full reaction: 

Ministers are pushing ahead with this politically-motivated fire sale of Royal Mail to fill the hole left by George Osborne’s failed plan. This is taking place despite opposition from a huge coalition including the Conservative Bow Group, the Countryside Alliance, the National Federation of Subpostmasters, the cross party BIS Select Committee as well as Royal Mail employees themselves.

The Government has not addressed the huge concerns which remain on the impact the Royal Mail sale will have on consumers, businesses and communities, but ministers are ploughing on regardless.

7.46am BST

Will Royal Mail staff suffer once the company is in private hands? Michael Fallon denies it, saying terms and conditions will be absolutely the same after privatisation.

Asked about the looming strike action (see 7.36am), the business and enterprise minister argues that staff have little to complain about.

They're being offered an 8.6% pay rise over three years*, and free shares too, at a time when nurses and teachers are only getting 1% per year, he points out, adding:

That sounds like a pretty generous offer.

• - The unions, though, are pushing for a better pay deal, and have rejected the offer of an 8.6% pay rise over three years.

Updated at 8.10am BST

7.42am BST

Michael Fallon, Minister of State for Business and Enterprise, is defending the Royal Mail selloff on Sky News now.

Fallon says it's a "hugely exciting day" for Royal Mail, and that the flotation will allow it to access private capital through the City to fund expansion plans.

He denies that the sale will lead to heavy job losses, pointing out that 50,000 positions have been cut over the last decade as "ministers dithered".

7.36am BST

Here's the statement which the government issued to the City this morning.

Royal Mail: Announcement of Intention to Float

7.36am BST

Unions will fight hard against the Royal Mail privatisation, with a strike ballot expected on 20 September.

That could be followed by a strike as early as 10 October - which would be the first nationwide postal strike since 2009.

7.29am BST

Five key points

So how does the Royal Mail privatisation work? Here's five key points from this morning's announcement:

• It's coming soon. The government announcement says " the IPO expected to take place in the coming weeks".

• The government hasn't announced exactly how much of Royal Mail is being sold. It says that it will "retain flexibility" until it sees investor demand and market conditions

• Royal Mail staff are getting free shares. 10% of the flotation will be set aside for 150,000 "eligible UK-based Royal Mail employees" 

• Anyone in the UK can take part in the sale, with the government hoping for a return to the "Tell Sid" spirit of the 1980s. Members of the public must bid for at least £750 of shares (this minimum application size is reduced to £500 for staff)

• Shareholders are being promised chunky returns. The statement says the Royal Mail intends to pursue a "progressive dividend policy" - City code for a decent-sized slice of the company's profits. It expects to hand back £133m in the first year (it would be £200m if the company had been listed for a full 12 months).

Updated at 8.58am BST

7.24am BST

Vince Cable, business secretary, declares that the selloff is the final stage of the government's plan to reform Royal Mail:

By announcing today that we intend to move ahead with a sale of shares in Royal Mail, we are completing the third and final part of the reforms agreed by Parliament two years ago.

This delivers on the commitment in the Coalition Agreement to give Royal Mail access to private capital, including opportunities for employee ownership.

7.09am BST

Royal Mail privatisation announced

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

Breaking News to kick off the day: The UK government has announced plans to begin the privatisation of Royal Mail.

The news, which broke last night, will see the business floated on the London Stock Market "in the coming weeks".

It could raise up to £3bn for the Treasury, but the sell-off is already being attacked by unions who fear it will lead to job losses and a worse service for parts of the UK.

Full details and reaction to follow.

The other big event coming up this morning is in Westminster. Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, will locks horns with MPs on the Treasury committee this morning to discuss last month's quarterly inflation report.

The hearing begins at 10am BST.

Carney will have to defend his bold pledge to peg UK interest rates to their current record low of 7% until unemployment rate has dropped to 7%, sometime in 2016 by the Bank's reckoning.

With the UK economy showing encouraging signs of growth, and the jobless rate falling to 7.7% yesterday, MPs may question the wisdom of this forward guidance.

He may also be asked for his views on today's Guardian front page story, about the surge in employment at estate agents.... 

I'll be tracking all the events through the day as usual....

Updated at 7.13am BST
fields.bodyText: Time for a round-up of today's Royal Mail news. • The UK government is preparing to take the historic step of privatising the Royal Mail in the face of union opposition and likely industrial action. This morning's announcement of a stock market flotation "in the coming weeks" received an angry response from workers, who refused to be swayed by chief executive Moya Greene today. Ballot papers on whether to strike for a better deal on pay, conditions and job protection will be sent out next week. Strikes could begin before November, despite staff bring promised around £2,000 worth of free shares each. • Business minister Michael Fallon spent most of the day insisting that privatisation will benefit Royal Mail, its customers and staff. Fallon told parliament that the universal service obligation -- guaranteeing six-day deliveries across the UK -- would remain under parliament's control. Stamp prices would still be regulated by Ofcom, he said. • Still, a series of opposition MPs criticised the plans. Labour accused the government of a firesale, to patch up the country's finances, and claimed the sale would lead to a deteriorating service. Shadow business secretary Chuka Umunna was scathing, saying the government has 'nationalised the losses' of Royal Mail, but was now 'privatising the profits'. MPs also feared that the company could end up in the hands of a foreign firm, with some harking back to the 1980s privatisations. Highlights of the debate start at 12.08pm.... Here are some of the best quotes from the debate. • Union members showed solid opposition to the plan, booing and jeering Moya Greene at a meeting in Birmingham. Details here. Unite's general secretary, Len McCluskey, summed up the mood - saying the Government was selling off the family silver. He added: This move is being driven by blinkered right-wing dogma that has ridden roughshod over public opinion which is strongly opposed to the sell-off of this national institution • City analysts, though, expect strong demand for Royal Mail shares -- especially as Labour is not committing to reversing the privatisation. • Business leaders have welcomed the move, with the Institute of Directors calling it a "great opportunity". • Our financial editor Nils Pratley analysis the float here • Rupert Neate explains how City firms will share £20m of fees • Our Q&A on the float explains how it will work • And here's our full news story on the plans: Royal Mail sell-off 'within weeks' We'll have more coverage of the float on www.theGuardian.com through the evening, and in tomorrow's newspaper. Goodnight! With 1,200 votes cast in our poll so far, two-thirds of readers say they are not planning to subscribe for shares in the Royal Mail flotation: You can still vote here. The Royal Mail float means a multi-million pound payday for the City. Around 20m has been set aside to pay the cost of the IPO, and investment bankers will walks away with most of the cash. Goldman Sachs and UBS will collect the vast majority of the advisory fees. Rupert Neate flags up that the payouts could have been even bigger, but the government demanded that the banks took on the work at a discounted rate. More here: Royal Mail flotation: banks to collect millions for advisory role Royal Mail is no longer the ailing, loss-making service of a few years ago. That means the flotation looks inevitable, despite union opposition. So argues writes my colleague Nils Pratley tonight. He also explains exactly why Royal Mail is able to cut its borrowing costs through new loans and credit facilities with commercial banks, rather than borrowing from the Business department. It's a bit rich for trade minister Michael Fallon to argue that the Royal Mail must be privatised because the business needs to be spared an annual competition for capital with schools and hospitals. The reality is that the government has been lending to Royal Mail on terms that would almost make a New York hedge fund blanch. Royal Mail's latest annual report gives the details. At the last balance sheet date, the company owed £973m and was paying an average interest rate of 8.8%. But this included a £473m slug of debt akin to a payment-in-kind note, a device commonly found in leveraged buyouts. Interest on that loan was rolling up at 12% – a nice little earner for a government that can still borrow for 10 years at 3%. Not surprisingly, the Royal Mail said on Thursday that refinancing with banks would lead to "a significant reduction" in its cost of debt. You bet. More here: Royal Mail privatisation looks inevitable - but the commercial case is weak The CBI has just thrown its support behind the flotation. Katja Hall, its chief policy director, said: Businesses across the country rely on postal services so this decision will ensure that the Royal Mail has the money it needs, from private capital, to invest and stay competitive in the years ahead. With the Institute of Directors swiftly backing the IPO this morning, the traditional battle lines between the unions and management are being drawn... And here's ITV News's take: Royal Mail strike action set for delay The word from the unions tonight is that a strike can't come as early as October 10, as first thought. Paperwork issues need to be resolved -- to do with the CWU's membership list. That means ballot papers probably won't be posted until some next week, not tomorrow as initially planned. That has a knock-on effect on the timetable for industrial action. The CWU needs to make sure it keeps safely within the law with any strike action -- otherwise it could give Royal Mail management the opportunity to block the walkout. Back in May 2010, a strike vote at British Airways was ruled unlawful because the Unite union had not informed its members about the vote (although a judge later overturned this ruling) A couple of other articles to flag up... Observer economics editor Heather Stewart warns that Mark Carney could be losing his lustre, following the Bank of England governor's appearance at the Treasury Committee this morning. She writes: After two gruelling hours, it was painfully clear that [interest rate] forward guidance, far from increasing clarity, has cluttered up the Bank's intellectual furniture with knockouts, staging posts and all the rest – while giving Britain's ever-ready consumers just the excuse they don't need to go shopping. MPs seemed noticeably less charmed by the £872,000-a-year governor than at his last outing. Like every rock star at some point in his career, Carney looks in danger of falling out of fashion. More here: Mark Carney loses his cool as forward guidance fails to convince MPs Interestingly, committee chairman Andrew Tyrie also appears unimpressed with Carney: Elsewhere, economics professor Barry Eichengreen has warned that the eurozone faces a 'hard landing', even though the euro is more secure than last year. The problem -- its troubled banking sector. The banks remain weak. Now that the European Banking Authority has finally issued new prudential rules, they can get about the business of raising the capital they need as a buffer against losses. Société Générale has moved in this direction, but few other banks have followed so far. So long as European banks remain undercapitalised and overleveraged, a sustainable recovery supported by robust bank lending is unlikely. More here: Eurozone collapse has been avoided but a hard landing is still possible The Save the Royal Mail campaign are calling today "A good day for bankers – a bad day for customers", and claiming that the universal postal service is at risk. Mario Dunn, its campaign director, said: People in rural areas, small businesses and the elderly are all particularly vulnerable to what will be the inevitable price rises and rural service reductions. Privatising Royal Mail fires the starting gun on the race to end the universal postal service as we know it. A privately owned Royal Mail will not want to maintain loss making rural deliveries. The 2011 Postal Services Act allows it to opt out delivering loss making services. With price caps removed the consumer protections in place are extremely flimsy. It will not be long before we begin to see the worst excesses we have come to associate with other sectors such as banking. Save Our Royal Mail also says that 70% of the public oppose the sale of Royal Mail. Michael Fallon conceded as much in parliament, earlier, blaming it on confusion and misinformation (see 12.47pm). And here's a photo from outside the Communications Workers Union meeting in Birmingham today: The Press Association has pulled together some of the best quotes from this lunchtime's statement on the Royal Mail flotation. Conservative Robert Halfon (Harlow) raised concerns over the prospect of massive salaries being paid to Royal Mail's directors coupled with price hikes for consumers. He said: "I welcome the transfer of shares from Royal Mail to the Royal Mail workers but can you reassure my constituents that we won't go the way of the water companies, where the directors pay themselves huge wages and increase prices for consumers, and can you set out the consumer protection that there will be?" Mr Fallon replied: "There are no deal bonuses as part of this share sale, let me just absolutely reassure you about that, there are no deal bonuses for the senior management. "But the protection for the consumer has been laid down by this House in the statute in the Postal Services Act 2011 which you will recall two years ago. "The regulation has been set out and the price of the stamp will continue to be capped by the regulator. Veteran Labour backbencher Dennis Skinner said: "Do you recall that in the late eighties we had a wholesale privatisation of almost all the public utilities with the exception of this one? "And it was under what Mrs Thatcher called the 'share-owning democracy', it's almost like I can hear the same words from the Despatch Box today. "And what happened to that shareholding democracy? Almost without exception every single public utility is now owned abroad and ripping the British consumer off. "The only difference between now and then those lick-spittle Lib Dems have joined the Tories to privatise it. What an utter disgrace." Labour former minister Peter Hain said the obligation on Royal Mail to deliver to every house in the country mean it will be disadvantaged against competitors who do not have the same obligation. He said: "Why aren't you imposing the same obligations on competitors to the Royal Mail, like TNT, to deliver to every house in the land, that the Royal Mail has, which is very, very costly for the Royal Mail while they cream off the most profitable business?" Labour frontbencher David Hanson said the sale amounted to a transfer of assets to the richest as the less well-off would not be able to afford £750 in shares. The shadow home affairs minister said: "Given the minimum purchase of shares is £750 could you explain to me how my low-paid constituents, those on pensions, those unemployed, are going to retain a stake in what they already own? "Is this not just a transfer from all of us to the richest in society?" Mr Fallon said it was "standard" to set a minimum threshold and that it "reflects standard practice". He said: "We do hope that here will be sufficient opportunity for retail participation in this, those members of the public that want to subscribe I would not like to see them miss out." Shadow culture minister Clive Efford warned that people may end up having to collect their post rather than having it delivered. He said: "The Government can't have it both ways. It can't have a regulatory regime that allows services to be cherry-picked where they are profitable by the jackals that will buy the Royal Mail and then say it's going to protect the universal service. "We all know it's going to be broken up. Can you say at the Despatch Box does your description of the universal service include one that requires people to collect their mail at a central collection point rather than it being delivered door-to-door?" Mr Fallon said the requirement to deliver was in the USO and could only be changed by Parliament. We've heard a lot from Michael Fallon already...but here's a video clip of the business minister explaining how privatising Royal Mail will lead to more investment in services: David Cameron's tweet about protecting the Royal Mail "for hard working people" (see 11.40am) didn't impress everyone: Both the Conservatives and Labour are targetting the nation's toilers and strivers. George Osborne used the #hardworking hashtag after spending a few hours with night shift workers in July, while Labour also made its pitch for hard working types at the TUC conference this week. Royal Mail chief executive Moya Greene continues to argue against a strike, despite receiving a rough reception from staff in Birmingham this morning. I've taken the quotes from PA: The Government has initiated the process for Royal Mail's privatisation and has dispelled any doubt over the future ownership of the business. It is now time for Royal Mail and the CWU to come to a new agreement for our people going forward. Talk of a ballot for industrial action makes no sense when there is a significant three-year deal on the table and negotiations are ongoing. I understand our people's concern that they should have protections in place as Royal Mail is privatised, which is why we have proposed a ground-breaking three-year, legally-binding agreement including a highly competitive pay offer of 8.6%. But the company and our customers need protections too. We want to ensure that, in future, any disputes are settled through dialogue, mediation and arbitration. It is because our customers trust us and value the service we provide, that there should not be a strike at this crucial time. If businesses can't rely on us, they will look elsewhere to protect their own business. The CWU recognises the need for us to access capital. In government ownership we have had to compete with the NHS, schools, roads and defence. We will also pay less interest on our company debt in the private sector than we do in the public sector. Access to private capital and a successful company is the best way to ensure secure employment for our people, who will be given a meaningful stake in the business. We have done a lot for the people and our company, through a better more collaborative relationship. We need to build on that. At the end of the day, the most durable protection for everyone who works in this business is a successful Royal Mail trusted for reliability by the people whom we serve. Back in parliament, Labour's Pat McFadden has been ruing the day that the previous government abandoned its plans to partially privatise Royal Mail. That day was 1 July 2009, when Peter Mandelson admitted defeat over a bill that would have sold a stake in Royal Mail to a private buyer but left the taxpayer with a majority stake. McFadden says the lesson is that if you don't reform when you have the chance, someone else will do it for you. He told BBC News 24: I think there was an opportunity lost then, which we warned about at the time. McFadden said that union opposition to the plan helped to sink it, but also cited Labour's struggle to find a buyer who would pay enough for a minority stake. We also pulled out because we didn't believe we could get a good deal for the taxpayer. The question now is that whether the government can get a good deal. Today, though, Royal Mail's pension deficit has been placed on the government's books, and the business is now generating a healthy profits (with an operating profit margin of 4.4% this year). Royal Mail insiders confirm that CEO Moya Greene was booed by staff in Birmingham this morning. I guess we shouldn't be surprised, given the union's seemingly resolute opposition to privatisation. Greene can't be accused of wilfully ignoring workers, since joining Royal Mail in 2010. For starters, she's attended the CWU's annual conference in the past to make her case and hear from the union. Ralph Ferrett, of the Plymouth and East Cornwall branch of the CWU, reports that that Moya Greene failed to sway workers in Birmingham this morning: The CWU's South Wales / South West Division echoes this sentiment: Rightly or wrongly, it looks like industrial action remains a real possibility. Royal Mail chief executive Moya Greene has apparently been booed by workers, at a meeting between management and workers today. That's according to a member of the Communications Workers Union, who attended the private event in Birmingham this morning. Kye Dudd, from the Bristol & District branch of the CWU, has tweeted that Greene was booed when she arrived on stage, and again when she finished explaining the plan. Apparently the hall rang to chants of "Royal Mail not for sale" as her appearance ended. In between, she was apparently "laughed at" when she told staff that she didn't understand why they were considering strike action. The media weren't allowed in, alas, but Dudd has tweeted several photos from Birmingham. And that's the end of business minister Michael Fallon's statement (scroll back to 12.08pm for full highlights). The key points: • Fallon insists that the flotation will help Royal Mail invest in its services. It will mean higher prices for consumers, and the Universal Service Obligation remains in parliament's control. "Scare stories" about a worse service for the Armed Forces, or the blind, are untrue, he said. • Fallon also claims that the Royal Mail and the Post Office will keep working closely together. He pointed to the 10-year deal signed in 2012, arguing that the two entities will always benefit from close links. • Fallon hopes that a strike can be avoided, if unions accept the 'enhanced' pledges being offered by Royal Mail management. • Opposition MPs have deep reservations about the sale, though. Shadow minister Ian Murray argued that in the long-term, a privately owned Royal Mail could force concessions from the government. Many MPs aren't convinced that prices will not rise, despite Ofcom's control over stamp prices. And finally, Labour's Stephen Timms says Fallon's promises will be little comfort to consumers looking at their "regulated energy bills". Fallon repeats that the price of a second class stamp is fixed, and a first class stamp must remain affordable - in the view of Ofcom. Asked about the prospect of job losses, Fallon says that 50,000 positions have been cut in the last decade. Won't Royal Mail staff simply sell their free shares? Fallon says no - there's a three-year lock-in. And they'll get dividends over that period. Glenda Jackson says that taxpayers will lose out because the flotation will be priced too cheaply, to ensure the shares are sold. Fallon replies that the government is determined to get "maximum value" Fallon is asked why TNT, the private delivery firm, criticised the plan. Fallon suggests TNT is "a little nervous" about the prospect of competition. Will Royal Mail be sold to a private firm? Fallon says it will have multiple owners, including its staff. Millions of owners. The government has decided not to sell to a foreign owner. Why don't the public support the privatisation? Fallon replies that there are some members of the public who "don't understand" how the postal system has been separated. Some have been influenced by untrue scare stories. But there's no support for nationalising electricity or water networks, he says. Asked to commit that there will be no changes to the six-day deliveries, or collections from post boxes, Fallon says such issues are covered by existing licencing. Chi Onwurah, Labour MP for Newcastle Upon Tyne, reminds Fallon that she used to work for Ofcom, where she learned that privatisation only works if you have competition at the supply point. Are we really going to have "multiple posties" on UK streets? Fallon says we already have competition in the postal market. Conservative MP Andrew Percy claims that Labour rivals use a commercial rival to the Royal Mail when they send out campaign literature. Fallon replies that Labour need to lay out whether they would reverse the flotation. Fallon claims that "several unfortunate scare stories" have emerged recently (in answer to a question about the Safe Our Royal Mail campaign). There is absolutely no threat to the current arrangements to the blind, to the armed forces... They are not being changed by this announcement. Several MPs are asking for reassurances on future prices. On stamps, Fallon says that the price of a second class stamp is fixed by Ofcom, while a 1st class stamp must remain "affordable" under the rules. Julian Smith, Conservative MP for Skipton and Ripton, congratulates Michael Fallon for succeeding where the Prince of Darkness failed. That's Peter Mandelson, of course. The agreement that ensures Armed Forces get cheaper postal services will continue after the flotation, said Fallon. Only Parliament can make significant changes to the Universal Service Obligations, Fallon reiterates. Could the Universal Service Obligation be diluted to make people collect their mail at their local Post Office? No, Fallon says. Conservative MP Richard Graham, who chairs the all-party group on postal issues, says privatisation isn't always best, so he welcomes the news that the Post Office is safe. He backs the flotation of Royal Mail. Green MP Caroline Green says this is an ideological sale. How can we guarantee that the sale will benefit the many, not the few? Fallon says he hopes that millions of people will benefit, by buying shares. Managers will not get bonus payouts through the flotation, Fallon says. Dennis Skinner says it's a repeat to Thatcher's share-owning democracy. We sold off out firms in the 1980s, and what happened? They are now owned by foreign firms. Consumers will suffer from this flotation, he adds. Michael Fallon says he doesn't want to return to the days where the state owns car companies, and water and energy firms. The price of stamps will still be set by the regulator -- so the public can't suffer higher prices through this deal. Asked about the union's opposition, Fallon says he hopes that they will not strike and support the IPO. He also asks how many workers will reject their offer of free shares. Michael Fallon points out that Deutsche Post is investing £600m per year in its services. Royal Mail needs to be able to do the same. Sir Edward Leigh points out that the Royal Mail privatisation has been an idea for two decades. It's the longest fire sale in history. Onto Questions. Katy Clark asks whether Royal Mail workers will suffer worse working conditions after privatisation. Fallon replies that there is already competition in the market, with parcels forms such as TNT. He adds that the Royal Mail is offering new guarantees to the unions. Fallon responds. The Universal Service Obligation is laid down in statute. Only a vote in parliament could change it, and we have no plans to do so. He adds that the details of the USO could be changed through secondary legislation, but there are no plans. The price of stamps is safe too. And the Royal Mail and Post Office have a 10-year deal to work together. Finally, Fallon criticises Murray for saying it is a fire sale - as Labour planned, and failed, with a partial privatisation when it was last in office. Labour needs to say what it would do about Royal Mail if it returned to office, he conludes. Murray asks whether the universal service obligation is protected by primary, or secondary legislation. Could the minimum and maximum service levels change? How firm is the alliance between Royal Mail and the Post Office? And when will the IPO take place? The government is playing politics with the Queen's head, he concludes. Murray rejects Fallon's claim that the universal service obligation is safe. What will happen if a future privatised Royal Mail asks for new legislation to loosen the terms of the USO, arguing that it is financially unsustainable? And how can we be sure that the Royal Mail won't target its £380m annual contract with the Post Office networks to cut its costs? Ian Murray, the shadow business, innovation and skills minister, replies for the opposition. He begins by expressing thanks to Royal Mail staff for working through the uncertainty of recent months. This is a politically motivated firesale, to patch up black holes in George Osborne's budget, he claims. Any suggestions that the privatisation of Royal Mail will lead to changes in the universal service obligation are completely unfounded, business minister Michael Fallon. And the Post Office is not for sale. It remains a separate company There will be no repeat of the closure programme conducted by the previous Labour government, says Fallon. Instead, the government will continue to invest in post offices. Fallon says that he and Royal Mail both understand the "apprehension" that staff feel about the plan. The float, though,will not impact staff terms and conditions. Royal Mail is offering staff "enhanced" three-year pledges on how the company will run, including no new outsourcing. Michael Fallon is giving a statement in Parliament on the Royal Mail privatisation now. He's running through the statement released this morning - confirming that staff will get free shares, that the IPO will begin in coming weeks, and that the government intends to sell a majority of the Royal Mail. The Save Our Royal Mail campaign is warning that rural services are going to suffer: Mario Dunn, campaign director of Save Our Royal Mail, said: This might be good news for the bankers but it is bad news for Royal Mail customers. The elderly, people in rural areas and small businesses will be particularly hard hit by the inevitable price rises and service reductions that will follow this privatisation. Royal Mail is a successful public sector enterprise. This is an unnecessary and ultimately political privatisation. A bit more from Mark Carney's testimony at Parliament (full live coverage here) 1) The Bank of England governor has insisted that he's not afraid to raise interest rates, pointing out that he's the only boss of a G7 central bank who's actually hiked borrowing costs (in Canada). 2) Carney declined to contrast his pledge that interest rates will remain low for some time with the UK government's declaration that the economy is healing. While there's been a "welcome" change in the pace of activity in the economy, the Bank wants to reinforce this through its monetary policy stance. He's proving a tricky customer for the Treasury committee to pin down.... Prime minister David Cameron tweets that the Royal Mail selloff is good news for the public, particularly 'for hard working people'. The British Chambers of Commerce is more cautious than the IoD. It says that it's essential that the universal service obligation is protected after Royal Mail is floated. Dr Adam Marshall, the BCC's director of Policy and External Affairs, said it is "crucial" that the group doesn't drop its focus on UK firms. He's not opposed to privatisation, but nor is he hailing it as a guaranteed winner. Marshall said: An efficient, effective postal service is a critical part of Britain’s business infrastructure. Regardless of Royal Mail’s future ownership structure, services that support British business must remain at the heart of the company’s mission and obligations. Many public services, including the post, can be delivered well by private companies. The key to a successful flotation is to ensure that the universal service obligation, both to businesses and individuals, is guaranteed. Ofcom will continue to act as the Royal Mail's regulator after privatisation, which means guaranteeing "a financially sustainable universal postal service in the UK". While unions and opposition politicians cry foul, the plan to float the Royal Mail on the stock market has been cheered by UK bosses. Simon Walker, Director General of the Institute of Directors, argues that a privatised Royal Mail will be able to improve service delivery by borrowing to invest. Walker also urged staff to embrace the privatisation, rather than launching industial action. He said: The Royal Mail is a vital service that businesses depend on, and Michael Fallon is absolutely right that now is the time to allow it to access to the capital markets, enabling it to invest in its future. We welcome the news that shares will be offered for sale to institutions and the public before the end of the financial year. Royal Mail employees should see this as a great opportunity, not only to own a stake in their company, but also to give it the best chance to succeed in a competitive delivery market. The unions must acknowledge that strike action is not in the best interests of the business or their members. The experience of European mail services shows that privatisation can improve the experience for customers. Can any European readers comment on this? There's been more heat than light in Westminster, where Bank of England governor Mark Carney's appearance before MPs has been bogged down in arguments over his new forward guidance on interest rates (no rate rise until the unemployment rate drops to 7%). Carney has been refusing to say whether the pledge is a loosening, or a tightening, or monetary policy. Or neither. Andrew Sparrow has the key exchange in his Live Blog. Carney has just told Andrew Tyrie that Tyrie did not correctly summarise his view, because he focused on long-term rates, not the shape of the yield curve. Q: Overall, have you loosened monetary policy? Carney says his announcement has reinforced the recovery. Q: Has it tightened or loosened policy? Carney says it has made it more effective. It has made it "more stimulative at the margins". Q: So you have loosened it? Carney says it has made it more effective. Tyrie says he has never heard a central bank governor saying he has made policy less effective. Eventually Carney says that, if Tyrie wants, he can describe it as loosening. Tyrie says it is going to be hard "down the Dog and Duck" deciding whether monetary policy has been loosened. (Do they ever talk about monetary policy down the Dog and Duck? I doubt it.) Business minister Michael Fallon will make a statement to the House of Commons on the Royal Mail IPO, at 12.30pm BST. Details here. Confirmation that the Scottish Nationalist Party also opposes the Royal Mail IPO. Mike Weir, SNP MP, argued it was another example of London-centric politicians ignoring rural communities: This is a deeply flawed Westminster decision, which threatens to have particularly harmful consequences for Scotland where so many of our rural communities and so much of our rural economy rely on our existing Royal Mail service. The UK Government are refusing to heed the real and genuine concerns that privatisation will mean a reduction in rural services as companies cherry-pick and compete in the larger urban areas. Given our experience of previous privatisations no one believes that the regulator will provide real protection to consumers on either prices or services. The Scottish Government has invested heavily in a scheme to bring fibre optic broadband to 95% of the population by 2017. That gives a real opportunity to grow rural businesses, but it requires an efficient, comprehensive and reasonably priced mail service to back it up. A privatised service will not deliver that for rural Scotland. Royal Mail must be viewed as part of our national infrastructure not just as another business. The Communications Workers Union will make the Royal Mail privatisation a key issue at the Labour Party annual conference in Brighton, the week after next. Billy Hayes, CWU general secretary, wants Ed Miliband to promise to nationalise Royal Mail again -- something that shadow business secretary Chuka Umunna refused to pledge at 9.12am this morning. There could be fireworks. Here's Hayes' full statement: This isn’t about what’s best for the Royal Mail, it’s about vested interests of government ministers’ mates in the City. Privatisation is the worst way to access to capital as it’s more expensive than borrowing under public ownership. There’s no competition with money for schools and hospitals as the government would have you believe – look at Network Rail which has borrowed billions on private markets at cheaper rates under an arrangement which doesn’t affect public debt. This is simply about dogma from old-fashioned Tories wedded to privatisation. We remain convinced that privatisation is the wrong decision for Royal Mail. It would be bad for customers, bad for staff and bad for the industry. Privatisation would put jobs and services at risk and lead to higher prices for customers. We’ve seen it happen time and again in other industries. We’re taking this to Labour Party Conference and we want a commitment that a Labour government would renationalise Royal Mail if privatised. Privatisation is an old-fashioned idea and a breach of the public’s trust. It would destroy a centuries-old public service. It's business as usual at the Royal Mail this morning, with staff cracking on with the job of moving letters and parcels around the UK, as this photo from Bethnal Green sorting office shows: Royal Mail is unlikely to end up in the FTSE 100 index, home of blue-chip giants, after privatisation. It will probably have to rough it in the second-tier FTSE 250 index. Companies are added, and removed, from the FTSE 100 on a quarterly basis, depending on how their value has changed. Without any pricing details, analysts are estimating that Royal Mail will be valued at close to £3bn. Conveniently, a quarterly review took place yesterday, and Wood Group (market capitalisation £2.9bn) is getting the boot. Sports Direct (£4.3bn) is in. A £3bn valuation means Royal Mail is worth just a quarter of Cambridge chip firm ARM, whose semiconductors are found in many of the world's smartphones. A reminder of how digital communications have superceded the old business of physically transporting information. The Royal Mail sale has now been condemned by the UNI Global Union, which was particularly disappointed that the Liberal Democrat party didn't use their influence in the coalition to stop it. Its general secretary, Phillip Jennings, says: This is catastrophic for the postal service. It is politically driven and I find it stunning that the Liberal Democrats should cave-in. It is a disaster for small business and communities up and down the country. It spells good-bye to universal services, to affordable prices and to decent work. It is an open invitation to the vultures of private equity who will enjoy their chance to strip the assets. Bad economic news from the eurozone this morning has undermined hopes of a recovery in the European economy - which is key market for the Royal Mail's GLS division. First, industrial production fell by 1.5% in July compared with June, which is much worse than City economists had expected - Secondly, Greek unemployment has hit yet another record high, of 27.9% in June, from 27.6% in May. Proof that Greece's population continue to experience misery as its six-year slump continues. Most markets are in the red this morning, although the FTSE 100 is only down 20 points. The government must be watching the markets a little nervously, as any autumn rout could sink the Royal Mail sale. Here's the latest details: We'd love to know whether you're considering taking part in the Royal Mail flotation, so please vote in our poll. Will you buy shares in Royal Mail? Heads-up: Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, is about to testify at the Treasury select committee. He'll be discussing the Bank's most recent quarterly inflation report, his pledge to keep UK interest rates at record lows until unemployment falls, and (probably) fears that a house price bubble is being created. It will be streamed live here: Monetary Policy Committee August 2013 Inflation Report My colleague Andrew Sparrow will be live-blogging the whole session here: Mark Carney gives evidence to the Commons Treasury committee: Politics live blog This graphic shows how most of the Royal Mail's revenues come from its parcels and letters divisions, although its European parcels business, GLS, makes a decent contribution (with revenue of £1.5m, out of a total pie of over £9bn. More details here. As part of today's deal, the Royal Mail has also refinanced its debt. In City jargon it has agreed £600m worth of term loan facilities and an £800m revolving credit facility, to replace the loans currently provided by the government. These new new debt facilities will mean a "a significant reduction in the Group's overall cost of debt", it says -- in other words, it will be able to borrow from commercial banks at a cheaper rate than from the Department for Business. Good news for Royal Mail, but presumably a loss of revenue for the taxpayer (Robert Peston reckons it's paying an interest rate of 8.8% - roughly three times as much as the government can borrow for 10 years) The BBC's Robert Peston is also intrigued by the prospect of Royal Mail floating on the stock market in the midst of a strike action: I can certainly never remember any business being sold on the stock market at a time when it had been brought to a grinding halt by a strike. But that does not mean a flotation in those circumstances can't and won't happen. There is the very real, or perhaps surreal, prospect, of postal workers simultaneously downing tools (parking their trolleys) and subscribing a few hundred quid for Royal Mail shares. Business minister Michael Fallon suggested on Radio 4 this morning that industrial action is unlikely (our political correspondent Rowena Mason flags up) Speaking on the Today programme, Fallon acknowledged that staff have "concerns" about the future of Royal Mail but said he did not expect a proposed strike to go ahead. Echoing some of the points he made on Sky News (see 7.36am), Fallon said: I don’t think the strike is necessary...There's a very generous pay off on the table. They've been offered 8.6% over three years, and I think the rest of the public sector is only getting 1% a year. It’s a very generous pay-off, there are free shares on offer as well, so I don’t see any reason for a strike. But as I mentioned up at 8.07am, this morning's announcement clearly warns prospective investors that Royal Mail anticipates strike action on or after 10 October.... Rafael Behr, political editor of the New Statesman, reckons the sale could prove a hot potato for Labour if it can't promise to renationalise the Royal Mail service. It's not too late to stop the selloff, Umunna concludes - pointing out that unions will be meeting with the Royal Mail CEO Moya Greene later today. Chuka Umunna also dismissed the idea that members of the public will dash to buy Royal Mail shares, given the minimum allocation of £750 (or £500 for staff who want more than their £2,000 free allocation). If you're earning a lot of money in the Cabinet, that's not a lot of money, but it's a lot to the man on the street, he says. Umunna reiterates his point from this morning that the government is now privatising the Royal Mail's profits, having nationalised its losses by putting its pension deficit on the public books. Chuka Umunna, the shadow business secretary, is on BBC News 24 now, criticising the selloff: He warns that there's no guarantee in the long-term that a privatised Royal Mail won't sell off sorting offices and other operations in prime city locations, which could hurt customers. This is bad for consumers, and bad in particular for small businesses. But will Labour reverse the sale? Umunna says he can't make any commitments to renationalising Royal Mail in the future. It would be like writing a blank cheque. City firm ETX Capital reckons that the IPO will be priced "very attractively", to avoid the embarrassment of some shares being left unsold. Joe Rundle, head of trading, says: We expect it to be priced very attractively by the government in order to garner the demand to deem this IPO as a success given the importance surrounding it. The Financial Times also flags up that even Margaret Thatcher couldn't face selling off the Royal Mail, pointing out that at least 41% of the company will be offered to City institutions and the public, on top of the 10% handed to staff. Our full news story about the Royal Mail privatisation is now live, by Rupert Neate. Here's a flavour: The sell-off of the 497-year-old postal service is the most contentious privatisation since British Rail two decades ago, and is forcefully opposed by the unions, who are meeting with the Royal Mail chief executive, Moya Greene, on Thursday morning to once again voice their anger at the "great British flog-off". The Communication Workers Union (CWU) plans to disrupt the sale process by holding a strike ballot on 20 September, which could lead to a nationwide strike by 10 October. It would be the first nationwide postal strike since 2009. The union is also pushing for a better pay deal, after rejecting a 8.6% pay rise over three years. Billy Hayes, general secretary of the CWU, said 96% of Royal Mail staff oppose the sell-off, which "not even Thatcher dared do". Margaret Thatcher, who privatised British Gas, British Airways, British Telecom and dozens of other state-owned institutions in the 1980s, famously refused to countenance a sale of Royal Mail, saying she was "not prepared to have the Queen's head privatised". Government to float Royal Mail on stock exchange 'in the coming weeks' The privatisation has also been criticised by Paul Wheelhouse MSP, a member of the Scottish Nationalist Party in the Scottish Parliament. He fears it will lead to deteriorating services in rural areas It's all the European Union's fault, according to UKIP's Nigel Farage: That's a reference to the EU's Postal Directive, which aims to create a Single Market for postal services. The EU has denied in the past, though, that it is responsible for the closure of rural post offices (there's a rebuttal online here), saying that its laws 'enshrine' the universal service obligation. The government helped to pave the way for the sale last year by transferring the Royal Mail pension fund (and its historic deficit of over £9bn) onto the public books. This makes the business rather more attractive to private buyers, as Labour's Chuka Umunna tweets: On page 15 of today's Announcement, the government warns potential investors that members of the Communications Workers Union will probably go on strike next month, possibly as early as 10 October. That strike action is over pay, pension reforms, the impact privatisation will have on staff, and the Royal Mail future strategy. Here's the key section: • Negotiations between Royal Mail and the CWU are continuing and Royal Mail remains committed to reaching an agreement with the CWU and averting industrial action. However, there can be no guarantee that negotiations will lead to a successful outcome or the aversion of industrial action. • Royal Mail currently believes that the relevant members of the CWU will vote for national industrial action and that national industrial action and other forms of industrial action are therefore expected to take place across the whole of UKPIL's activities on or after 10 October 2013. In the event of national industrial action, the Group has contingency plans in place and will also consider its legal options Could the government push through the Royal Mail selloff before unions have the chance to strike? ITV's Laura Kuenssberg reckons so, writing that "the race is on" to get the share sale out of the door before October 10 - the earliest possible day for a strike action. That sounds potentially risky -- will investors really want to snap up shares in a company whose staff are poised to walk out?.... George Thomson, general secretary of the National Federation of Sub-Postmasters, has also heavily criticised the plan: I am extremely disappointed and concerned that the Government is pressing ahead with a plan that will undoubtedly jeopardise the future of thousands of post offices. We simply have not had the promised new Government work that needs to be delivered before the sale of Royal Mail and which would safeguard the future survival of an independent Post Office. Thomson has called for the government to "halt the sale" until this new work is forthcoming -- unlikely, I suspect, given Michael Fallon's obvious enthusiasm on Sky News a few minutes ago. He also wants the government to hold a significant share of the company after privatisation, to give the public some control over their postal service (today's announcement simply says the government "intends to dispose of a majority of Royal Mail’s issued share capital"). The Labour party has blasted the decision to begin floating Royal Mail on the stock market. Chuka Umunna, the shadow business secretary, says there's a "huge coalition" against the plan, but ministers are "ploughing on regardless". Here's his full reaction: Ministers are pushing ahead with this politically-motivated fire sale of Royal Mail to fill the hole left by George Osborne’s failed plan. This is taking place despite opposition from a huge coalition including the Conservative Bow Group, the Countryside Alliance, the National Federation of Subpostmasters, the cross party BIS Select Committee as well as Royal Mail employees themselves. The Government has not addressed the huge concerns which remain on the impact the Royal Mail sale will have on consumers, businesses and communities, but ministers are ploughing on regardless. Will Royal Mail staff suffer once the company is in private hands? Michael Fallon denies it, saying terms and conditions will be absolutely the same after privatisation. Asked about the looming strike action (see 7.36am), the business and enterprise minister argues that staff have little to complain about. They're being offered an 8.6% pay rise over three years*, and free shares too, at a time when nurses and teachers are only getting 1% per year, he points out, adding: That sounds like a pretty generous offer. • - The unions, though, are pushing for a better pay deal, and have rejected the offer of an 8.6% pay rise over three years. Michael Fallon, Minister of State for Business and Enterprise, is defending the Royal Mail selloff on Sky News now. Fallon says it's a "hugely exciting day" for Royal Mail, and that the flotation will allow it to access private capital through the City to fund expansion plans. He denies that the sale will lead to heavy job losses, pointing out that 50,000 positions have been cut over the last decade as "ministers dithered". Here's the statement which the government issued to the City this morning. Royal Mail: Announcement of Intention to Float Unions will fight hard against the Royal Mail privatisation, with a strike ballot expected on 20 September. That could be followed by a strike as early as 10 October - which would be the first nationwide postal strike since 2009. So how does the Royal Mail privatisation work? Here's five key points from this morning's announcement: • It's coming soon. The government announcement says " the IPO expected to take place in the coming weeks". • The government hasn't announced exactly how much of Royal Mail is being sold. It says that it will "retain flexibility" until it sees investor demand and market conditions • Royal Mail staff are getting free shares. 10% of the flotation will be set aside for 150,000 "eligible UK-based Royal Mail employees" • Anyone in the UK can take part in the sale, with the government hoping for a return to the "Tell Sid" spirit of the 1980s. Members of the public must bid for at least £750 of shares (this minimum application size is reduced to £500 for staff) • Shareholders are being promised chunky returns. The statement says the Royal Mail intends to pursue a "progressive dividend policy" - City code for a decent-sized slice of the company's profits. It expects to hand back £133m in the first year (it would be £200m if the company had been listed for a full 12 months). Vince Cable, business secretary, declares that the selloff is the final stage of the government's plan to reform Royal Mail: By announcing today that we intend to move ahead with a sale of shares in Royal Mail, we are completing the third and final part of the reforms agreed by Parliament two years ago. This delivers on the commitment in the Coalition Agreement to give Royal Mail access to private capital, including opportunities for employee ownership. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world. Breaking News to kick off the day: The UK government has announced plans to begin the privatisation of Royal Mail. The news, which broke last night, will see the business floated on the London Stock Market "in the coming weeks". It could raise up to £3bn for the Treasury, but the sell-off is already being attacked by unions who fear it will lead to job losses and a worse service for parts of the UK. Full details and reaction to follow. The other big event coming up this morning is in Westminster. Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, will locks horns with MPs on the Treasury committee this morning to discuss last month's quarterly inflation report. The hearing begins at 10am BST. Carney will have to defend his bold pledge to peg UK interest rates to their current record low of 7% until unemployment rate has dropped to 7%, sometime in 2016 by the Bank's reckoning. With the UK economy showing encouraging signs of growth, and the jobless rate falling to 7.7% yesterday, MPs may question the wisdom of this forward guidance. He may also be asked for his views on today's Guardian front page story, about the surge in employment at estate agents.... I'll be tracking all the events through the day as usual....
fields.headline: Strikes loom as Royal Mail privatisation announced - as it happened
fields.trailText: UK government fires the starting gun on controversial privatisation of Royal Mail, setting up battle with unions

webTitle: 'No recovery yet,' says Next boss

fields.standfirst: Simon Wolfson, CEO of retailer, argues that sustainable recovery is impossible until people stop getting poorer
fields.body:
The UK will not enjoy a sustainable economic recovery until people stop getting poorer, Simon Wolfson, the chief executive of high street retailer Next, has warned. He said the high street was benefiting from a more buoyant housing market and more confident consumers. But he warned: "In real terms, people are still getting poorer. The retail economy has benefited from the elimination of the credit squeeze but that needs to be translated into growth of real earnings for a sustained recovery." His comments echo those of Ed Balls, the sShadow chancellor Ed Balls has warned that "life is getting harder" for ordinary families.

Wolfson said there was every chance a wider recovery would emerge, but it would take at least a year. "It is a mistake to believe we are in the recovery now," he said.

His comments come as Next has revealed a 2.2% rise in sales over the most recent six months, while profits rose 8.2% to £272m.

webTitle: Morrisons cuts back big store growth to focus on small shops and online service

fields.standfirst: 'The future is no longer in building big supermarkets. The space race is well and truly over,' says chief executive Dalton Philips
fields.body:
The supermarket "race for space" is history, Morrisons said on Thursday as it joined Tesco in scaling back big store growth to focus on online shopping and smaller convenience stores amid slowing sales and profit.

Britain's fourth biggest supermarket said it would limit expansion from 2014 to less than half of the average rate of growth in its supermarket space over the last five years, as it prepares to launch its online delivery service in partnership with Ocado from January.

Chief executive, Dalton Philips, echoed rival Philip Clarke, the boss of Tesco as he said: "The future is no longer in building big supermarkets. The space race is well and truly over."

Morrisons estimated that its step back from opening more large stores would result in a 29% fall in capital expenditure in 2014/15 to £850m, and to £650m thereafter. Shares in the company rose nearly 2% as investors hoped the supermarket would now use some of its spare cash to return funds to shareholders.

Clarke said a new share buyback programme was not ruled out as Morrisons also revealed that it would be reviewing ways to raise cash from its £9bn property portfolio.

The company will examine options such as selling and leasing back some of its stores, 90% of which is held on a freehold basis. The retailer suggested that while the majority of its estate would continue to be owned, new stores would be taken on a leasehold basis.

"We expect to see the proportion of freehold properties reduce naturally as our convenience store programme expands. ," Morrisons said.

Hopes of a potential pay-out offset concerns about a 22% fall in pre-tax profit to £344m in the first half. Morrisons said the fall was partly the result of investment in convenience stores and online markets, which it hopes will increase the size of its potential market by 40%.

It included a £27m writedown against the retailers' efforts to develop its own online business, following the deal with Ocado. Like-for-like sales fell 1.6%, while turnover in the first half to 4 August was flat at £8.9bn.

Philips said he was "encouraged by the direction of travel," even though Morrisons continues to lose market share.

Analysts said Morrisons still had something to prove. "The group has yet to execute. Both profits and same store sales have fallen, with the group's slow adoption of both convenience stores and an online proposition allowing rivals to gain market share, which will be tough to regain," said Keith Bowman, analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown.

Philips said Morrisons was "working to ensure we are fit for the future", playing catch-up with its peers in developing 21st century IT systems, moving online and getting into the fast-growing convenience store market. Morrisons has 33 local convenience stores and is on track to boost this to 100 by the end of the full year.

Philips said he remained cautious about the consumer outlook and wasn't expecting any "significant change" in the near future. "Whilst early indications of a recovery in the UK economy are encouraging, we are yet to see this impact on consumers' pockets," he said.

In a separate trading update Morrisons' online partner Ocado said sales in the 12 weeks to 11 August rose 16.4% to £189.2m.

webTitle: Tesco and the end of the supermarket space race

fields.bodyText: Tesco boss Philip Clarke called a halt to the supermarket space race last autumn as he admitted that shoppers were falling out of love with large out-of-town supermarkets. He said people were "opting out of stores" as they switched to buying online and picking up food when they needed it at local convenience shops. At the same time, supermarkets have realised that they make little profit from selling furniture and electrical goods, which take up large amounts of space. Tesco slashed its UK expansion plans in half with around 110 development sites no longer slated to be turned into supermarkets and a further 40 plots of land next to existing stores were put on the market after store extensions were abandoned. The grocer is also hacking back up to 50 of its biggest supermarkets, and subletting space to other retailers and other businesses, such as gyms and childrens play centres, which it hopes will draw in families. Meanwhile, Tesco has invested in Giraffe, the restaurant chain, and coffee shop Harris + Hoole to try to make its more cavernous outlets more family-friendly destinations.

webTitle: John Lewis Partnership profits fall nearly 40%

fields.bodyText: A holiday pay underpayment and a bill for redundancy costs led to a near 40% dive in half-year profits at the John Lewis Partnership despite strong sales. The group, which owns 39 department stores and the Waitrose supermarket chain, said sales rose 7.3% to more than £4.7bn in the six months to July as it won market share from rivals in fashion, homewares and electricals as well as groceries. Waitrose sales rose 7.8% while John Lewis department store sales climbed 6.6% despite the tough economic climate. The partnership had to pay out £40m to employees after the group discovered it had miscalculated holiday pay over several years. It also faced a £15m charge, mostly related to job cuts among department store managers. Those two items wiped 38.5% off half-year profits to £68.5m. The chairman, Charlie Mayfield, said the partnership had no plans for further job cuts "on that scale," but there could be no guarantee against further restructuring as growth online outstrips high street performance. He expected to keep up the strong pace in the second half of the year as both businesses benefit from a link-up in which John Lewis goods ordered online can be picked up at Waitrose stores. The retailer says 2013 will be the first "mobile Christmas" as shoppers use their phones and tablet computers to order an increasing amount of goods via the internet. More than 40% of John Lewis's online sales now come via handheld devices and Mayfield says this is likely to increase in the next few months. His hopes for a strong Christmas have been boosted by better signs on the economy but he cautioned: "My view is the recovery will be long and not in a straight line." While the department stores continue to see like-for-like growth, Mayfield said two-thirds of customers now shopped via both the stores and the internet, where sales rose 17%. Waitrose sales online rose 41% during the half year and it is to open a second "dark store" to handle demand for home deliveries in London. It is scheduled to open by the second half of next year. Waitrose continues to open more stores with long-term plans to have as many as 600 stores around the country, compared with 300 at present. The grocer said it was encouraging shoppers by signing up 2.5 million to its myWaitrose loyalty scheme, which had helped encourage more return visits. Mayfield said the department stores were now looking at introducing a loyalty programme as a result.

webTitle: Bank of England governor Mark Carney rattled as he defends forward guidance

fields.bodyText: Bank of England governor Mark Carney on Thursday defended his plan to keep interest rates low for up to three years as MPs voiced concerns that it may be confusing the public and had failed to convince investors. Carney said the central bank's policy of forward guidance was supporting the recovery and encouraging consumers and businesses to spend. Under tough questioning from MPs on the Treasury select committee the new governor said the pace of growth was picking up, but remained in its early stages and could be knocked off course. The fragile nature of the recovery, he said, meant there was no reason to bring forward interest rate rises, which have remained at 0.5% for the last four years. He insisted: "Overall, my view is that the announcement has reinforced recovery. It's made policy more effective, and more effective policy is stimulative at the margin." Last month the BoE's monetary policy committee said that so long as inflation stayed under control it would only consider pushing interest rates to more normal levels once unemployment fell to 7%. The MPC forecast that unemployment would remain above the new target until the second half of 2016. In a speech in Nottingham last month Carney said the target was a trigger point to discuss a rise in rates rather than a threshold that would immediately force a rate rise. He also outlined how three "knockouts", including a jump in inflation beyond 2.5%, would force the MPC to reconsider its low interest rate policy. Several MPs said it remained unclear how the MPC will react to improvements in the economy. Some City analysts predict the unemployment rate will fall to 7% at least a year earlier than forecast by the MPC. Andrew Tyrie, the committee's Tory chairman, complained that Carney's account of the Bank's new approach would be difficult to explain "down the Dog and Duck". After the meeting he said: "Credibility in monetary policy is hard won and easily lost. The new framework – with its target, threshold and 3 'knockouts' – is more complex to explain than its predecessor. Rightly, the Bank is now engaged in bolstering credibility in its new framework with detailed explanations." He added: "Confidence in monetary policy will be enhanced where those detailed explanations provide greater certainty about the likely responses of the Bank as circumstances change." Andrea Leadsom MP said she was concerned that the MPC had "watered down" its inflation target. "I am still slightly bemused how the inflation target ranks alongside the new unemployment target," she said. Asked about the plight of savers, whose savings are being eroded by inflation with interest rates at rock bottom, the governor said he had "great sympathy", but the best thing the Bank could do to help was to generate a sustainable economic recovery. "Our job is to make sure that that's not another false dawn, and ensure that this economy reaches, as soon as possible, a speed of escape velocity, so that it can sustain higher interest rates." Carney stressed that despite the MPC's expectation that rates will remain on hold for up to three years, he would be ready to push up borrowing costs if necessary. "I'm not afraid to raise interest rates," he said, pointing out that he is the only serving central bank governor among the G7 countries to have increased rates – in his previous post, in Canada. City investors have pushed up long-term borrowing costs in financial markets sharply since the MPC announced its three-year pledge to leave borrowing costs unchanged at 0.5%. But Carney, who was handpicked by George Osborne to kickstart recovery and took over in Threadneedle Street at the start of July, said the recent increase in rates, which sent 10-year government bond yields through 3% last week for the first time in more than two years, was a result of the recovery and "benign". He also repeatedly refused to be drawn on whether the new approach represented a loosening of policy – equivalent to a reduction in interest rates – in itself. He said forward guidance made the current stimulus of low rates and £375bn of quantiative easing more effective.

webTitle: Royal Mail flotation: banks to collect millions for advisory role

fields.standfirst: Goldman Sachs and UBS set to earn lion's share of about £20m of government cash paid out to banks, lawyers and PR firms
fields.body:
Bankers, lawyers, accountants and PR firms will collect millions of pounds of government cash from advising on the Royal Mail flotation, with investment banks alone earning around £15m.

One of the biggest winners from the deal will be Mark Sorrell, the son of the advertising tycoon Sir Martin Sorrell. As the co-head of UK investment banking at Goldman Sachs, Mark Sorrell is one of two top bankers working on the deal alongside fellow Goldman partner Richard Cormack.

Goldman and UBS will collect the vast majority of the advisory fees, which could easily top £20m, according to a senior banking source.

Banks typically collect up to 4% of the value of a flotation, which would work out at just over £100m if the government floats 90% of the company. But they often charge higher fees for flotations involving sales to the general public, due to the added complexity.

The government, aware of the potential public backlash against banks getting rich from the sale of a venerable institution, is understood to have demanded the banks take a much lower cut, possibly as low as 1%.

The Department for Business refused to state the fees paid to any of its advisers, but said it had "negotiated very hard to get the best value for taxpayers".

Details of the fees will be published in the sale prospectus in the next couple of weeks. If the fees are set at 1% the banks would collect about £15m if half of the company is floated.

Barclays, Bank of America, Merrill Lynch, Lazards, Investec, Nomura and the Royal Bank of Canada will also collect fees for working on the deal.

Alec Mattinson, deputy editor of PR Week, said three City firms promoting the privatisation – Tulchan Communications, Brunswick and Citigate Dewe Robertson – would collect "a decent six-figure whack".
